Wednesday 2nd November 2011
Curriculum Information
Dear Parents,
As announced to you earlier in the school year, the Secondary Department will no longer be sending home a weekly blurb containing curriculum information. This blurb will now be replaced with a far more detailed curriculum letter. Attached to this letter is the curriculum information for all subjects for the remainder of this Autumn Term. In January a new curriculum letter will go home containing information for the Spring Term and a final letter will go home in April with details for the Summer Term.
If you have any questions pertaining to the information contained in this curriculum letter, please speak to the individual teachers at our parent teacher conferences over the next two weeks.
Kind regards
Mrs. Hamilton
Key Stage Three Phase Leader
Autumn Term 2 – Curriculum Map (Year 7)
English
Holes
Phonics, spelling and vocabulary · Spell correctly most words used. · Increase knowledge of word families, roots, derivations, morphology and regular spelling patterns. · Learn a range of vocabulary appropriate to their needs, and use words precisely in speech and writing to clarify and extend meaning and to interest their audience. Grammar and punctuation · Comment on the use of formal and informal language and discuss the writer’s motivation for making the choice. · Show awareness of the reasons for using longer and shorter sentences. · Begin to comment on the control of pace and meaning through choice of sentences and variety of sentence openings. · Writing · Use a wide range of punctuation to make meaning clear, including generally accurate use of commas in complex sentences and to present dialogue. · Use correct grammar, including articles, word order and tenses in a range of genres and text types. · Clarify relationships between ideas with an increasingly accurate and growing use of connectives. · Provide clarity and emphasis in writing, using a variety of sentence lengths, structures and subjects. · Use a range of increasingly complex sentence structures to communicate meaning and to give fluency to their writing. · Build up detail and convey shades of meaning through sentence structure, e.g. controlling order of clauses, expanding verb phrases.
Reading: · Demonstrate understanding of features of narrative and non-narrative texts by explaining and developing these features in their own discussion and writing. · Use inference and deduction to recognise implicit and inferred meanings. · Identify and understand the main ideas, viewpoints, themes and purposes in a text. · Support comments by quotation from more than one location in the text. · Identify and describe the effect of writers’ and poets’ use of literary, rhetorical and grammatical features, including imagery and figurative language. · Comment on a writer’s use of language, demonstrating an understanding of the implication of their use of vocabulary. · Give an informed personal response to a text and provide some textual reference in support. · Understand how readers make choices about the texts they like reading, e.g. by author or genre and know a range of ways in which to respond to texts. · Compare poems, showing awareness of poets’ use of language and its intended impact on the reader. · Understand the different ways texts can reflect the social, cultural and historical contexts in which they were written.
Writing: · Shape the overall organisation, sequence and presentation of a text to convey ideas clearly and effectively. · Mirror the purpose of the writing by appropriate use of paragraphs and selection of linking words and phrases. · Use vocabulary precisely and imaginatively to clarify and extend meaning and create specific effects. · Vary sentence length and structure in order to provide appropriate detail and clarify relationships between setting, characters, themes, plot, etc.
Fiction · Identify and understand the main ideas, viewpoints, themes and purposes in a text. · Support comments by quotation from more than one location in the text. · Identify and describe the effect of writers’ and poets’ use of literary, rhetorical and grammatical features, including imagery and figurative language. · Comment on a writer’s use of language, demonstrating an understanding of the implication of their use of vocabulary.
Poetry: An Introduction to Poetry · Discuss the appeal and importance of texts from drawn from different historical times, including contemporary · Perform poetry using drama conventions · Comment on rhyme and the rhythmic style of poems, and relate this to their themes · Draw on reading and knowledge of linguistic and literary forms when composing writing · Convey themes, ideas and arguments imaginatively · Play with language and explore different ways of discovering and shaping meaning · Using inventive approaches to create effect. · Use a range of ways to structure and organise work to guide the listener · Use a range of techniques to explore, enrich and explain their ideas · Use imaginative vocabulary

French
Unit 2 : Mes passions (My favourite things) Grammar focus : verbs · Les sports (sports): We will be able to identify different names of sports in French and learn how to express an opinion on these sports. · Mes fêtes préférées (special occasions; dates, age, birthday) : We will learn different French celebrations while revising dates and the negative form of a sentence. · C’est le week-end! (week-end activities, likes or dislikes) : We will learn new verbs to describe our week-end activities (using the grammatical form : pronoun + verb +infinitive verb) and the negative form of a sentence. · Copains-copines (You and your friends) : We will learn how to introduce and describe someone focusing on how to build a sentence with every pronouns and possessive adjectives. PE
Field Hockey/ Fitness Testing Pupils will continue to develop their understanding of the Principles of Play by taking part in Field Hockey. Pupils will develop technical skills such as passing, shooting, tackling, blocking and dribbling. Firstly, pupils will learn a variety of ball control and dribbling skills. These will include the ball check, drop step, speed dribble, power dribble, Indian dribble and spin dribble. Secondly, pupils will develop their use of passing in both stationary practices and in more competitive situations. All skills will be refined and practiced in competitive match situations in order to enhance the pupils ability to make effective decisions. As well as skills, pupils will be given ample opportunity to develop strategic and tactical thinking relating to the principles of play. These thinking skills will allow the pupils to transfer them across all invasion games. Towards the end of this term, pupils will take part in a variety of fitness tests. This will allow them to identify their strengths and weaknesses and suggest ways in which they can improve. All tests will be retaken in term two and three.
Key Skills: -Dribbling and Ball Control – Ball check, drop step, speed dribble, power dribble, Indian dribble, spin dribble -Tackling – Jab tackle, forehand block tackle, reverse block tackle -Shooting – Quick hit, deflection shot, dive shot, edge shot, chip shot -Tactics and Strategies – Principles of play in attack and defense.
